questions.text: What is the most common malignancy that develops in a renal transplant recipient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Skin and lip cancers are the most common malignancies in renal transplant recipients, primarily due to chronic immunosuppression, which impairs immune surveillance and allows oncogenic viruses and mutated cells to proliferate unchecked.

The most commonly observed malignancies in this population are:

  • Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the skin and lip
  • These cancers occur more frequently and behave more aggressively in transplant recipients than in the general population.

The risk is especially high for:

  • Fair-skinned individuals
  • Those with long-term sun exposure
  • Patients on long-term immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., calcineurin inhibitors, azathioprine)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Urothelial cancers (Option A):

These are increased in some transplant recipients, particularly in certain geographic areas (e.g., Taiwan, where aristolochic acid exposure is prevalent), but they are not the most common overall.

Renal cell carcinoma (Option B):

While the native kidneys of transplant recipients are at increased risk for RCC, especially if there is cystic kidney disease, RCC is still less common than skin cancers in this group.

Colorectal carcinoma (Option D):

There is a modest increase in colorectal cancer risk among transplant recipients, but it is far less common than skin and lip malignancies.

choices.text: In renal transplantation, Kidneys with high KDPI are allocated to those expected to have high post-transplant survival.
Living donor transplants fare better than deceased donor kidneys
Immunosuppression is required lifelong for patients after transplant, except if donated by an identical twin or simultaneous kidney-bone marrow transplantation.
ATG and Alemtuzumab are used as depleting agents

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • KDPI (Kidney Donor Profile Index) is a score that predicts the expected longevity of a donor kidney.
  • A high KDPI (>85%) indicates lower expected graft survival, meaning the kidney is from a donor with higher risk factors (e.g., older age, comorbidities).
  • These kidneys are typically not allocated to recipients with high expected post-transplant survival (e.g., young and healthy patients), but rather to older recipients or those with lower life expectancy, in order to match organ longevity with patient prognosis and maximize utility.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Living donor transplants fare better than deceased donor kidneys (Option B)

  • Living donor kidneys have superior outcomes in terms of graft survival, function, and fewer delays in transplant due to elective timing.

Immunosuppression is required lifelong after transplant, except if donated by an identical twin or simultaneous kidney-bone marrow transplantation ( Option C)

  • Long-term immunosuppression is essential to prevent rejection.
  • Exceptions include:
    • Monozygotic (identical) twin transplants (no alloimmune response)
    • Combined kidney-bone marrow transplant with successful chimerism, where tolerance can develop.

ATG and Alemtuzumab are used as depleting agents (Option D)

  • ATG (Anti-thymocyte globulin) and Alemtuzumab (anti-CD52) are lymphocyte-depleting induction agentsused to prevent acute rejection post-transplant.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases presents with Thrombotic microangiopathy without Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

POEMS syndrome (Polyneuropathy, Organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal gammopathy, Skin changes) is a rare paraneoplastic syndrome associated with plasma cell dyscrasia.

It can be associated with TMA-like lesions on renal biopsy, especially glomerular capillary wall thickening and endothelial damage, but without overt MAHA.

Hence, TMA without microangiopathic hemolytic anemia may occur in POEMS syndrome.

Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) is a pathological process involving endothelial injury, leading to thrombosis in small blood vessels, which typically presents with:

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA): characterized by schistocytes on blood smear
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Organ dysfunction, particularly renal involvement

However, not all causes of TMA present with full-blown MAHA.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Malignant Hypertension (Option A):

  • Causes TMA due to vascular shear stress and endothelial damage.
  • Commonly presents with MAHA, including schistocytes, elevated LDH, low haptoglobin, and thrombocytopenia.

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (Option C):

  • Classic example of TMA.
  • Presents with MAHA, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury, particularly in children (often post-diarrheal).

HELLP Syndrome (Option D):

  • A serious complication of pregnancy involving Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelets.
  • It is a TMA syndrome and features MAHA

choices.text: Neurological involvement in HUS is as common as in TTP
TTP is more common in adults and HUS in children.
Atypical HUS occurs due to dysregulation of classical complement pathway

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Atypical HUS (aHUS) is caused by dysregulation of the alternative complement pathway, not the classical pathway.

This can be due to genetic mutations in complement regulatory proteins (e.g., factor H, factor I, MCP) or autoantibodiesagainst them.

The classical pathway involves antigen-antibody complexes and is not the primary driver of aHUS.

Typical HUS:

  • Common in children
  • Occurs following a bloody diarrhoes.
  • Most common causative agent is Shiga toxin producing enterohemorrhagic E.coli O157:H7. Other agent is Shigella dystentriae.
  • Toxin binds to glycolipid surface receptor in renal microvascular endothelium and enters the endothelial cells and activates inflammatory cytokines and causes platelet activation.
  • MAHA occurs within 1 week of bloody diarrhoea.
  • Neurological symptoms are as common as in TTP.
  • Fever is typically absent.
  • Streptococcus pneumonia produce neuraminidase that cleaves Thompson Friedenreich Antigen on platelets and endothelium. This is a cryptic antigen, which is recognized by IgM and causes MAHA.

Atypical HUS:

  • Occurs due to defect in alternate complement pathway.
  • Factor H deficiency is the most common cause-inherited.
  • Factor H inhibits the activation of Alternate pathway C3 convertase, in the absence of factor H, there will be dysregulated activation of the alternate complement pathway.
  • C3 will be low and C4 will be normal.
  • Autoantibody to factor H results in a specific type of atypical HUS called DEAP HUS. It is very severe and causes ESRD.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Neurological involvement in HUS is as common as in TTP (Option A):

This is true. Although neurological symptoms are classically associated with TTP, such as confusion and seizures, HUS-especially severe or atypical forms-can also present with neurological involvement. The overlap in clinical presentation makes differentiation challenging without ADAMTS13 testing.

TTP is more common in adults and HUS in children (Option B):

This is true. Typical HUS is commonly seen in children, especially following infections with Shiga toxin-producing E. coli. In contrast, TTP usually occurs in adults, often related to an acquired deficiency of ADAMTS13.

Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause HUS (Option D):

This is true. S. pneumoniae-associated HUS occurs primarily in young children and is thought to be related to neuraminidase activity, which exposes the T-antigen on red blood cells, leading to hemolysis and endothelial injury.

choices.text: HELLP Syndrome can be a possible differential diagnosis
TTP can be triggered by pregnancy
Renal impairment is life threatening in HELLP
ADAMTS 13 activity can be decreased in HELLP syndrome also.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female, who was 32 weeks pregnant is brought to the ER, with 1 week history of fever. She had been complaining of sever fatigue, decreased urine output and high coloured urine. This morning she developed two episodes of seizures and is unconscious. There were no focal deficits and both the plantar were extensor. Her investigations showed Hb: 6g/dL, Total Count of 20,000 cells/μL, Platelet of 10,000/μL, S. Cr was 4.5mg/dL. Her peripheral smear showed shistocytes. Her Prothrombin time and activated thromboplastin time were normal. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

While renal impairment can occur in HELLP syndrome, it is not typically the most life-threatening feature. The most serious and life-threatening complications in HELLP are:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Liver rupture
  • Severe thrombocytopenia with bleeding
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Placental abruption

Renal involvement is more prominent and severe in TTP or HUS, and while HELLP may involve mild to moderate renal dysfunction, life-threatening renal failure is not characteristic of HELLP syndrome. Therefore, this statement is false and the correct answer.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

HELLP Syndrome can be a possible differential diagnosis (Option A):

This is true. The patient is a pregnant woman at 32 weeks gestation with hemolysis (schistocytes, low Hb), elevated liver enzymes (assumed), low platelets, seizures, and renal dysfunction - all of which overlap with HELLP syndrome. However, TTP is also a strong possibility in this scenario.

TTP can be triggered by pregnancy (Option B):

This is true. Pregnancy is a known trigger for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), especially in the third trimester or postpartum period. TTP in pregnancy is a medical emergency and can mimic HELLP syndrome, making differentiation challenging.

ADAMTS13 activity can be decreased in HELLP syndrome also (Option D):

This is true. While a severely reduced ADAMTS13 level (<10%) is characteristic of TTP, mild to moderate reductions in ADAMTS13 activity have also been observed in HELLP syndrome. Therefore, ADAMTS13 testing can support but not definitively differentiate between the two.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man has a new-patient screen carried out by his GP. He is noted to have microscopic haematuria. His GP also notes a raised ESR and a calcium concentration of 12.4 mg/dl. On examination he appears to have a varicocele. What diagnosis fits best with this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 68-year-old man presents with microscopic haematuria, hypercalcemia (serum calcium 12.4 mg/dL), a raised ESR, and a varicocele. These features together are highly suggestive of renal-cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC often presents subtly and may be incidentally detected, but classic features include haematuria, flank mass, and systemic symptoms. The elevated ESR reflects inflammation, and hypercalcemia can result from a paraneoplastic syndrome-commonly due to secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP). A varicocele, particularly if right-sided or of recent onset, may indicate obstruction of the gonadal vein by a retroperitoneal mass such as RCC. This collection of findings aligns well with renal-cell carcinoma, making it the most appropriate diagnosis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Transitional-cell carcinoma (Option A):

Transitional-cell carcinoma affects the renal pelvis, ureters, and bladder, and can cause hematuria. However, it is not commonly associated with paraneoplastic syndromes like hypercalcemia or a raised ESR. It also does not typically present with a varicocele, which is more characteristic of renal cortical or retroperitoneal masses.

Wilm's tumour (Option B):

Wilm's tumour (nephroblastoma) is a tumour of early childhood, usually occurring before the age of 5. It is exceedingly rare in adults, and a diagnosis in a 68-year-old would be highly unlikely. Therefore, this option is not appropriate.

Retroperitoneal sarcoma (Option C):

Retroperitoneal sarcomas can cause mass effect and potentially compress structures like the gonadal vein, leading to varicocele. However, they do not typically cause haematuria or hypercalcemia, and are far less common than RCC. The absence of direct renal involvement also makes this less likely.

questions.text: A 1 year old boy presents with renal insufficiency. Upon evaluation he has evidence of portal hypertension and dilation of intra hepatic bile ducts. Which protein mutation is he likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This clinical scenario describes a 1-year-old child with:

  • Renal insufficiency
  • Portal hypertension
  • Dilated intrahepatic bile ducts

This constellation is characteristic of Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD). ARPKD typically presents in infancy or early childhood with:

  • Enlarged echogenic kidneys with collecting duct dilation
  • Congenital hepatic fibrosis, leading to portal hypertension
  • Dilated intrahepatic bile ducts (Caroli's disease pattern)

ARPKD is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene, which encodes fibrocystin/polyductin, a protein involved in the development and maintenance of renal collecting ducts and biliary ducts.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Polycystin (Option B):

Polycystin-1 and -2 are involved in Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD), which typically presents in adulthood, not infancy. ADPKD is associated with renal cysts, intracranial aneurysms, and liver cysts, but not congenital hepatic fibrosis or portal hypertension.

Hamartin (Option C):

Hamartin is encoded by the TSC1 gene, mutated in Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC). TSC can cause renal angiomyolipomas and cysts, but does not cause portal hypertension or bile duct dilation.

Tuberin (Option D):

Tuberin is the product of the TSC2 gene, also associated with Tuberous Sclerosis. Like hamartin, it does not fit the clinical picture of portal hypertension with bile duct dilation.

choices.text: Intra cranial bleed due to vascular aneurysm

questions.text: A 15 year old boy is found to have bilaterally enlarged kidneys replaced by multiple cysts of varying sizes. His father had undergone nephrectomy on the left side for a benign neoplasm of the kidney. What is he at risk for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 15-year-old boy has bilateral renal enlargement with multiple cysts of varying sizes, which is classic for Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD). Though ADPKD typically presents in adulthood, early-onset cases can occur in adolescents.

The clue that his father had a nephrectomy for a "benign neoplasm" is suspicious and points toward a familial predisposition to renal tumors. While the term "benign neoplasm" might have been used loosely, individuals with ADPKD have a higher risk of developing renal cell carcinoma (RCC), particularly if there is a family history.

Although RCC is not the most common complication of ADPKD (renal failure is), it is an important potential malignancy risk in these patients, especially when there is a family history suggestive of renal tumors.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Renal insufficiency and ESRD (Option A):

While this is a common complication of ADPKD, especially in adulthood, the question specifically asks what the patient is at risk for based on current findings and family history. The family history of nephrectomy for a renal mass raises concern for malignant transformation, making RCC a more specific and relevant answer in this case.

Intra cranial bleed due to vascular aneurysm (Option B):

ADPKD is indeed associated with berry aneurysms, which can rupture and cause subarachnoid hemorrhage. However, there is no mention of neurological symptoms or a relevant family history of intracranial hemorrhage in this case. So while this is a valid complication, it is not the most directly indicated in this specific question.

Hepatic fibrosis (Option D):

Hepatic cysts are common in ADPKD, but hepatic fibrosis is more characteristic of Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD), not ADPKD. This child's age and family history are more consistent with ADPKD.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with weakness, general malaise and ankle swelling. He has been unwell for 4 months, the ankle swelling having developed quite rapidly over the previous 3 weeks. On examination he has marked peripheral oedema and 3+ proteinuria without haematuria on dipstick urinalysis. His daily urine albumin excretion rate is measured at 6.9 g/24 hours, creatinine is 1.30 mg/dl, serum albumin is 1.2 g/dl and Hb is 8.9 g/dl. Further investigation reveals a paraprotein band in his serum with kappa light chains demonstrated on immunofixation. What is the probable cause of the proteinuria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with features of nephrotic syndrome (marked peripheral oedema, 6.9 g/day proteinuria, low serum albumin), alongside normocytic anaemia, and a paraprotein band with kappa light chains detected on immunofixation. These findings are characteristic of light-chain deposition disease (LCDD)-a condition where monoclonal light chains (usually kappa) deposit in the glomerular basement membrane and tubular basement membranes, leading to nephrotic-range proteinuria and progressive kidney dysfunction.

Unlike amyloidosis, the light chains in LCDD do not form beta-pleated sheet fibrils, and thus do not stain with Congo red. Kidney biopsy would show nodular glomerulosclerosis (similar to diabetic nephropathy), and immunofluorescence would reveal linear deposits of kappa light chains.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Cast nephropathy (Option A):

Also known as myeloma kidney, this occurs when filtered free light chains precipitate within the distal tubules, forming obstructive casts. It typically presents with acute kidney injury, minimal proteinuria on dipstick (as light chains are not albumin), and not nephrotic syndrome. In this case, the patient has nephrotic-range albuminuria, making cast nephropathy unlikely.

Tubulointerstitial nephritis (Option B):

This typically causes mild proteinuria, no nephrotic features, and is often associated with systemic symptoms like fever, rash, and eosinophilia. It leads to renal dysfunction but is not a cause of heavy albuminuria or low serum albumin to this extent.

Amyloidosis (Option D):

Can also cause nephrotic syndrome with a paraprotein, but in AL (primary) amyloidosis, the light chains typically form amyloid fibrils that stain Congo red positive. Amyloidosis is more commonly associated with lambda light chains, not kappa. Additionally, the absence of Congo red staining (implied by the diagnosis) and the presence of kappa light chains point more toward LCDD.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male is diagnosed with multiple myeloma and is awaiting treatment initiation. He presents to the casualty with lethargy, increased thirst and decreased urine output of 2 days duration. On examination, his BP is 110/70mm Hg, he is severely dehydrated. His Serum calcium is 14mg/dL His urinalysis shows mild proteinuria without RBC or cast. What is the cause of AKI?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 70-year-old male with known multiple myeloma presents with signs of acute kidney injury (AKI)-lethargy, dehydration, decreased urine output-and hypercalcemia (serum calcium 14 mg/dL). His urinalysis shows mild proteinuria without RBCs or casts, which is typical of non-glomerular causes of AKI.

In multiple myeloma, cast nephropathy (also known as myeloma kidney) is the most common cause of AKI. It occurs due to excessive filtration of free light chains (Bence Jones proteins), which bind with Tamm-Horsfall protein in the tubules to form obstructive casts, leading to tubular obstruction and inflammation.

Hypercalcemia, common in myeloma, worsens renal function by causing pre-renal dehydration and direct tubular injury, but cast nephropathy remains the principal mechanism of AKI here.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Tumor Lysis Syndrome (Option A):

This occurs after initiation of chemotherapy due to rapid cell lysis, leading to hyperuricemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperkalemia, and hypocalcemia. However, this patient has not started treatment yet and shows hypercalcemia, which goes against TLS. Tumor Lysis Syndrome is unlikely.

Amyloidosis (Option C):

Renal amyloidosis in myeloma presents more with chronic kidney disease and heavy proteinuria, often in the nephrotic range. It is not a common cause of acute kidney injury and would not present acutely with dehydration and hypercalcemia. This is a chronic process, not acute.

Light Chain Deposition Disease (Option D):

This is another light-chain-related kidney pathology, but it usually causes a glomerular pattern of injury with progressive renal failure and proteinuria, often without casts. AKI due to LCDD is less common than cast nephropathy in this setting. It does not typically cause abrupt AKI.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man visits his GP for a new-patient screen. His only previous complaints have been type-2 diabetes and mild long-standing back pain. Screening tests reveal an elevated serum creatinine of 2.15 mg/dl and anaemia with Hb of 10.1 g/dl. A back X-ray shows collapse of the lumbar spine and there is a monoclonal band on serum protein electrophoresis. What is the most likely cause of his deteriorated renal function?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely cause of this patient's deteriorating renal function is amyloidosis. He presents with elevated serum creatinine, anaemia, lumbar spine collapse, and a monoclonal band on serum protein electrophoresis. These features point toward an underlying plasma cell dyscrasia, likely AL (light-chain) amyloidosis, a condition where monoclonal light chains deposit in various organs-including the kidneys-causing progressive renal impairment. The vertebral collapsesuggests possible bone fragility due to amyloid infiltration or coexistent multiple myeloma, while normocytic anaemiaand chronic renal dysfunction support the systemic nature of the disease.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Diabetic nephropathy (Option A):

Although the patient is diabetic, diabetic nephropathy typically shows a more gradual decline in renal function and is usually accompanied by proteinuria and longstanding poorly controlled diabetes. In this case, the presence of a monoclonal band and vertebral collapse are not explained by diabetic nephropathy.

Membranous glomerulonephritis (Option B):

This condition usually presents with nephrotic-range proteinuria, not with vertebral collapse or a monoclonal protein band. While it can cause renal impairment, it doesn't explain the systemic signs or bone changes.

Metformin toxicity (Option C):

Metformin is contraindicated in severe renal failure due to the risk of lactic acidosis, but it does not itself cause progressive renal dysfunction or bone collapse. Moreover, metformin toxicity would present acutely with metabolic derangements, not chronically with a monoclonal spike and vertebral damage.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with polyuria and polydipsia of 2 months duration. He has been on a chronic medication for last 15 years. The urine is hypoosmolar. His blood sugars are normal. Which could be the drug?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lithium, used chronically (often for bipolar disorder), is well known to cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) as a side effect. In NDI:

  • Kidneys become resistant to ADH (vasopressin)
  • Resulting in polyuria, polydipsia, and hypoosmolar urine
  • Blood glucose is normal, ruling out diabetes mellitus
  • The chronic use (15 years) further supports this diagnosis

Thus, this patient's presentation is classic for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Phenytoin (Option A):

Although phenytoin has many neurological and dermatological side effects, it is not known to cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus or significant effects on renal water handling. Unlikely to explain hypoosmolar polyuria.

Amlodipine (Option C):

A calcium channel blocker, primarily used for hypertension. It does not impair ADH function or renal water conservation. Not associated with polyuria/polydipsia.

Metoprolol (Option D):

A beta-blocker used for cardiovascular conditions. It does not affect renal concentrating ability or cause diabetes insipidus. No known link to hypoosmolar polyuria.

questions.text: Which of the following stones form independent of urinary pH?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Calcium oxalate is the most common type of kidney stone and is not influenced by urinary pH. It can form in both acidic and alkaline urine. Risk factors include hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, and low urine volume, but pH does not play a major role in its formation-making it unique compared to other types of stones.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Uric acid stones (Option B):

Uric acid stones are highly dependent on urinary pH. They precipitate in acidic urine (typically pH < 5.5). Thus, urinary pH plays a key role in their formation, and they do not form independently of pH.

Calcium phosphate (Option C):

These stones form in alkaline urine (pH > 6.5), often seen in conditions like distal renal tubular acidosis. Hence, calcium phosphate stone formation is very much pH-dependent.

Cystine (Option D):

Cystine stones occur in patients with cystinuria, and their formation is favored by acidic urine. Increasing urinary pH is a mainstay of treatment. Therefore, these stones are not independent of urinary pH.

choices.text: Calcium phosphate stones are common in RTA and primary hyperparathyroidism
Potassium bicarbonate supplementation should be given to all patients with phosphate stones for alkalinizing the urine.
Dietary phosphate reduction may be beneficial.
Thiazides are used to reduce calcium excretion.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Potassium bicarbonate is not routinely recommended for all patients with phosphate stones, particularly calcium phosphate stones, because alkalinizing the urine can worsen their formation. Calcium phosphate stones form more readily in alkaline urine, so increasing urinary pH with potassium bicarbonate may exacerbate stone formation. Hence, this approach is contraindicated in such cases.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Calcium phosphate stones are common in RTA and primary hyperparathyroidism (Option A):

True. Calcium phosphate stones are frequently seen in conditions with alkaline urine, such as distal renal tubular acidosis (RTA) and primary hyperparathyroidism, both of which increase the risk of calcium phosphate crystallization.

Dietary phosphate reduction may be beneficial (Option C):

True. Lowering dietary phosphate can reduce urinary phosphate excretion, which may help reduce the risk of phosphate stone formation, particularly in patients prone to hyperphosphaturia.

Thiazides are used to reduce calcium excretion (Option D):

True. Thiazide diuretics decrease urinary calcium excretion and are commonly used to prevent calcium-containing stones, including calcium phosphate and calcium oxalate types.

choices.text: Uric acid excretion is reflected in serum uric acid levels.
Uric acid excretion is improved by urine alkalinization.
Reducing purine containing foods may be beneficial.
Allopurinol or Febuxostat can reduce uric acid excretion by 40-50%

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Serum uric acid levels do not reliably reflect urinary uric acid excretion. A person may have normal serum uric acid but still have high urinary uric acid, leading to uric acid stone formation. Similarly, individuals with elevated serum uric acid may not necessarily have high urinary excretion. Therefore, to assess the risk of uric acid stones, urinary uric acid levels (typically measured over 24 hours) are more informative than serum levels.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Uric acid excretion is improved by urine alkalinization (Option B):

True. Uric acid is more soluble in alkaline urine. Alkalinization (e.g., with potassium citrate) increases the solubility of uric acid and reduces stone formation.

Reducing purine-containing foods may be beneficial (Option C):

True. Purines are metabolized to uric acid. A low-purine diet helps reduce uric acid production and is beneficial for individuals with uric acid stones or hyperuricosuria.

Allopurinol or Febuxostat can reduce uric acid excretion by 40-50% (Option D):

True. Both drugs inhibit xanthine oxidase, thereby reducing uric acid production and subsequent excretion. This is especially helpful in patients with hyperuricosuria-related stones.

choices.text: Primary hyperoxaluria predisposes to calcium oxalate stones, renal parenchymal calcification and renal failure.
Male calcium oxalate stone formers should be advised not to take vitamin C.
Avoidance of purine rich diet is beneficial in preventing all types of stones.
Struvite stones does not require removal in most cases

questions.text: Identify false statement?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Struvite stones, also known as infection stones, form in the setting of chronic urinary tract infections with urease-producing organisms (like Proteus). These stones often grow rapidly and form large staghorn calculi, which can lead to obstruction, recurrent infection, and renal damage.

In most cases, struvite stones require complete removal because medical management alone is usually not sufficient. Even with antibiotic therapy, if the stone is not removed, infection tends to persist or recur. Surgical or percutaneous removal is often necessary.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Primary hyperoxaluria predisposes to calcium oxalate stones, renal parenchymal calcification and renal failure (Option A):

True. Primary hyperoxaluria is a genetic disorder leading to excess oxalate production, resulting in calcium oxalate stone formation, nephrocalcinosis, and often progression to ESRD.

Male calcium oxalate stone formers should be advised not to take vitamin C (Option B):

True. Vitamin C is metabolized to oxalate, and excessive intake can increase urinary oxalate excretion, predisposing to calcium oxalate stones, especially in men who are more commonly affected.

Avoidance of purine-rich diet is beneficial in preventing all types of stones (Option C):

True. While especially beneficial in uric acid stones, purine restriction can also help reduce calcium oxalate stone risk in patients with hyperuricosuria, which may promote calcium oxalate crystallization. So although not equally effective for all stone types, the advice has broad preventive value.

choices.text: Treatment if the c-reactive protein(CRP) is high
Treatment if the erythrocyte sedimentation rate(ESR) is high

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman presents with dysuria and increased frequency. A urinary tract infection is diagnosed. What is the most appropriate step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Urinary tract infections (UTIs) during pregnancy should always be treated, regardless of symptom severity, because of the increased risk of complications for both the mother and the fetus. These complications can include pyelonephritis, preterm labor, low birth weight, and intrauterine growth restriction. Even asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy warrants antibiotic treatment.

In this case, the woman is symptomatic (dysuria, frequency), confirming a symptomatic lower UTI. Prompt antibiotic treatment is essential to prevent progression and complications. A urine culture should be sent, and empiric antibiotics safe in pregnancy (e.g., nitrofurantoin, amoxicillin, or cephalexin) can be initiated while awaiting culture results.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

No treatment (Option A):

This is inappropriate. Untreated UTIs in pregnancy significantly increase the risk of ascending infection and adverse obstetric outcomes.

Treatment if the CRP is high (Option C):

CRP is a nonspecific inflammatory marker. Its level is not a criterion for treating a UTI in pregnancy. Waiting for CRP results could delay essential therapy.

Treatment if the ESR is high (Option D):

Like CRP, ESR is nonspecific and not useful in deciding whether or not to treat a UTI. Management is based on symptoms and urinalysis/culture, not inflammatory markers.

choices.text: Re-testing of urine with cytological examination after antibiotics

questions.text: An 86-year-old woman presented with her first episode of urinary tract infection. Urine examination confirmed blood and proteinuria and E. coli was grown on culture. What is the next step in management after treating her with antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In an 86-year-old woman presenting with her first UTI, the presence of blood (hematuria) and proteinuria raises concern for a possible underlying urological malignancy or another structural abnormality. Although Escherichia coliwas grown in culture - a common pathogen in UTIs - hematuria in an elderly patient, particularly when it is gross or persistent, warrants further evaluation after resolution of the infection, as inflammation or infection may obscure other pathology.

The appropriate next step after completing antibiotic treatment is to repeat the urine test, including cytological examination, to assess for urothelial malignancy or persistent abnormalities that may require further investigation. Urinary cytology is especially useful in detecting bladder cancer, which becomes more common with age and can present subtly.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Take no action (Option A):

This would be inappropriate in an elderly patient with hematuria and proteinuria, even in the setting of a first-time UTI. These findings may indicate underlying malignancy or glomerular disease, and should not be ignored.

Cystoscopy (Option B):

While cystoscopy is useful in evaluating persistent hematuria, it is not the immediate next step. It should be considered if hematuria persists on repeat testing after antibiotics or if cytology reveals atypical or malignant cells.

Retrograde pyelography (Option C):

This is an invasive imaging modality used for assessing the upper urinary tract, usually reserved for cases where non-invasive imaging (e.g., CT urography or ultrasound) is inconclusive or when there is suspicion of upper tract obstruction or malignancy. It is not indicated as the next step in this scenario.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to casualty with flank pain and a 48-h history of dysuria. Her past medical history includes polycystic ovarian syndrome. There is haematuria and proteinuria on urine dipstick testing. Examination reveals a pyrexia of 38.1°C and flank pain. What diagnosis fits best with this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 28-year-old woman presents with flank pain, fever, dysuria, hematuria and proteinuria, which are classic signs of acute pyelonephritis-a bacterial infection of the renal parenchyma. The fever (38.1°C) and flank tenderness support a diagnosis beyond simple cystitis. The presence of proteinuria and hematuria on dipstick adds evidence of kidney involvement, which is typical in pyelonephritis.

Although she has a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), this is unrelated to her current urinary and systemic symptoms.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Nephrolithiasis (Option A):

While flank pain and hematuria may occur in nephrolithiasis, fever and dysuria point more toward an infection. Furthermore, proteinuria is not typical in uncomplicated renal stones. The presence of fever suggests infection rather than just obstruction.

Pelvic inflammatory disease (Option B):

PID typically presents with lower abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, and possibly abnormal vaginal discharge-not flank pain. Moreover, hematuria and proteinuria are not characteristic findings in PID.

Ovarian cyst pain (Option C):

An ovarian cyst may cause unilateral pelvic pain, especially mid-cycle or with rupture. However, it does not cause fever, dysuria, or urinary findings such as hematuria or proteinuria.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE? Asymptomatic bacteruria needs treatment in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Asymptomatic bacteriuria is the presence of bacteria in the urine without signs or symptoms of a urinary tract infection. In most populations, it does not require treatment because it doesn't lead to adverse outcomes and overtreatment can promote antimicrobial resistance.

However, there are specific exceptions where treatment is recommended - and pregnancy is the most important one.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Individuals > 80 years of age (Option B):

Although asymptomatic bacteriuria is common in the elderly, treatment is not indicated unless there are symptoms of a urinary tract infection. Treating asymptomatic cases in this age group does not improve outcomes and can lead to harm from antibiotics.

Diabetic patients (Option C):

Despite higher risk of infections, routine treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria is not recommended in diabetics as it does not reduce the risk of symptomatic UTI or complications.

Boys < 1 year of age (Option D):

Routine screening and treatment for asymptomatic bacteriuria is not recommended in the absence of symptoms, though UTIs in infants should be carefully evaluated when symptomatic.

questions.text: A patient undergoes investigation for chronic upper urinary tract obstruction with intravenous urography. The patient should be informed about which severe complication?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intravenous urography (IVU), also known as intravenous pyelography (IVP), is a radiological procedure used to evaluate the structure and function of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. It involves the injection of iodinated contrast dye into a vein, which is then filtered by the kidneys and visualized using X-rays.

The most significant severe complication associated with IVU is hypersensitivity to the contrast dye. This can range from mild allergic reactions (e.g., rash, urticaria) to severe anaphylactic reactions, which are rare but potentially life-threatening. Therefore, patients should be screened for any history of contrast allergies or asthma, and informed consent should include discussion of this risk.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Ureter damage (Option B):

This is not a risk associated with intravenous urography, since the contrast is injected into a vein, not directly into the ureters. Ureteral injury is a concern in procedures like retrograde pyelography or ureteroscopy, but not IVU.

Skin reaction (Option C):

While minor skin irritation or rash can occur as part of a mild allergic response, it is not a severe complication and is usually self-limited. The major concern remains systemic contrast hypersensitivity.

Bleeding (Option D):

Bleeding is not a recognized complication of intravenous urography, as the procedure does not involve incisions or instrumentation of blood vessels beyond venipuncture, which is very low risk.

choices.text: Post obstructive diuresis is more common in unilateral than bilateral obstruction.
Large amount of hypotonic urine will be voided.
Electrolyte free water excretion may result in hypernatremia.
Urine output and urinary and serum electrolytes should guide the fluid replacement

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Post-obstructive diuresis refers to a marked increase in urine output that occurs after the relief of urinary tract obstruction. It can be a physiological response (to excrete excess water and solutes) or a pathological state (leading to excessive fluid and electrolyte loss).

Post-obstructive diuresis is more common and more severe in bilateral obstruction or in obstruction of a solitary kidney.

In unilateral obstruction (with a normal contralateral kidney), the unaffected kidney can compensate, reducing the risk of a massive diuresis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

(B): Large amount of hypotonic urine will be voided - True

  • This is correct. After relief of obstruction, there is impaired concentrating ability of the tubules, leading to large volumes of dilute (hypotonic) urine.

(C): Electrolyte free water excretion may result in hypernatremia - True

  • The excretion of free water without adequate replacement can result in hypernatremia, especially in patients unable to drink enough.

(D): Urine output and urinary and serum electrolytes should guide the fluid replacement - True

  • This is an important management principle. Careful monitoring is essential to avoid volume depletion, electrolyte imbalances, and complications like hypotension or arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with Parkinson's disease is referred to acutely by his GP having been found to have a creatinine of 5.5 mg/dl. He was known to have normal renal function two years previously. On examination he has evidence of rigidity, resting tremor and postural instability. He appears to have bilateral small pupils. He has a postural BP drop from 160/72 mm/Hg when supine to 138/60 mmHg when standing. Ultrasound shows bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and a hugely distended full bladder. Which cause of obstructive renal failure should be considered most likely unless proven otherwise?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 70-year-old man with Parkinson's disease presents with acute kidney injury (AKI) (creatinine 5.5 mg/dL), bilateral hydroureteronephrosis, and a distended bladder, indicating lower urinary tract obstruction. Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder that affects autonomic as well as somatic nervous system functions. A common urological complication in Parkinson's is neurogenic bladder, which results from impaired coordination of bladder detrusor muscle and sphincter control.

This patient also shows signs of autonomic dysfunction (e.g., postural hypotension and small pupils), supporting the presence of a dysautonomia, further increasing the likelihood of bladder dysfunction. A distended bladder with bilateral hydroureteronephrosis points to chronic lower urinary tract obstruction, with back-pressure effects on the upper urinary tract, leading to post-renal AKI.

Thus, the most likely cause of obstructive renal failure in this context is neurogenic bladder secondary to Parkinson's disease.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Benign prostatic hypertrophy (Option A):

Although common in elderly men, BPH would not explain the full constellation of findings as clearly as neurogenic bladder in a Parkinson's patient. Moreover, the presence of autonomic signs and a known neurological disorder make neurogenic bladder more likely.

Ureteric obstruction (Option C):

Bilateral ureteric obstruction is relatively uncommon and usually caused by stones, tumors, or fibrosis. It would not typically cause a distended bladder, which suggests the obstruction is below the bladder (i.e., bladder outlet level).

Retroperitoneal fibrosis (Option D):

RPF may cause bilateral ureteric obstruction but again would not typically cause bladder distension. It's a rare condition, and the patient has no known risk factors such as medications, malignancy, or prior radiation.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man is admitted hypothermic and unconscious, having been found collapsed on his kitchen floor. Biochemistry reveals a significant metabolic acidosis(bicarbonate 8 mmol/l), sodium 139 mmol/l, potassium 4.5 mmol/l, chloride 97 mmol/l and glucose 5.6 mmol/l. What is the likely biochemical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 73-year-old man presents hypothermic and unconscious, with biochemistry showing a severe metabolic acidosis(bicarbonate 8 mmol/L). To determine the most likely cause, we calculate the anion gap:

Anion gap = Na+ - (Cl- + HCO3-) = 139 - (97 + 8) = 34 mmol/L

This is a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, which significantly narrows the differential.

Given his clinical state (collapsed, hypothermic, unconscious) and high anion gap, the most likely biochemical cause is lactic acidosis. Lactic acid accumulates in conditions of tissue hypoperfusion or hypoxia, such as prolonged immobilization on a cold floor (possible rhabdomyolysis and poor perfusion), leading to anaerobic metabolism and lactate accumulation.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Alcohol intoxication (Option A):

Ethanol intoxication typically does not cause a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. If methanol or ethylene glycol were involved, a high anion gap would occur, but this would usually be accompanied by visual disturbances or renal failure. No such features are mentioned.

Diabetic ketoacidosis (Option B):

DKA presents with a high anion gap acidosis, but typically with markedly elevated blood glucose (often >13.9 mmol/L). This patient has a normal glucose level (5.6 mmol/L), making DKA unlikely.

Renal tubular acidosis (Option D):

RTA causes a normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis, not a high anion gap acidosis. Also, bicarbonate is usually low, but the anion gap remains normal - which is not the case here.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes with history of muscle weakness and lethargy. On examination his blood pressure is low. His Serum potassium is 2mEq/dL. His blood pH is 7.58 and HCO3 is 28mmol/dL, with low urinary calcium excretion. What is he likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 15-year-old boy presents with muscle weakness, lethargy, hypotension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis (pH 7.58, HCO 28), and low urinary calcium excretion-all of which point toward Gitelman's syndrome.

Gitelman's syndrome is a salt-losing tubulopathy due to a defect in the Na-Cl cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule.

Features include:

  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypotension
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Low urinary calcium excretion

Behaves like thiazide diuretic use.

Difference between barter and Gitelman syndrome

A): Bartter's Syndrome (Option A):

  • This also causes hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, but urinary calcium excretion is high in Bartter's.
  • Incorrect because this case describes low urinary calcium, which is against Bartter's.

(C): Liddle Syndrome (Option C):

  • Causes hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis due to increased sodium reabsorption via ENaC channels.
  • This patient has low BP, so Incorrect.

(D): Conn's Syndrome (Primary Hyperaldosteronism) (Option D):

  • Characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.
  • Again, this patient is hypotensive, so Incorrect.

choices.text: Genetic defect of the Na+-K+-2Cl- co-transporter
Pharmacological inhibition of the Na+-K+-2Cl- co-transporter

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman complains of weakness and lethargy. Clinical examination is normal with a blood pressure of 96/70 mmHg and no oedema. Her plasma creatinine concentration is 0.70 mg/dl and her potassium is 2.8 mmol/l. A blood test 3 years ago demonstrated a potassium concentration of 2.7 mmol/l. A urinary screen fails to reveal any diuretics. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral nephrocalcinosis. What is the probable tubular defect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most probable tubular defect in this case is a genetic defect of the Na+-K+-2Cl- co-transporter (Option C), characteristic of Bartter syndrome.

Bartter syndrome is a rare inherited disorder affecting the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. The defective Na+-K+-2Cl- co-transporter leads to impaired reabsorption of sodium, potassium, and chloride, resulting in:

  • Chronic hypokalemia (as seen in this woman),
  • Metabolic alkalosis,
  • Normal or low blood pressure (BP: 96/70 mmHg),
  • No oedema despite renal salt wasting,
  • Nephrocalcinosis, often seen on ultrasound,
  • And no evidence of diuretic use.

The long-standing hypokalemia with normal creatinine and absence of diuretics support this diagnosis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Abnormality of the aquaporin channels (Option A):

This refers to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, where defective aquaporin-2 channels in the collecting duct cause impaired water reabsorption, leading to polyuria, polydipsia, hypernatremia, and dilute urine. It is not associated with hypokalemia or nephrocalcinosis, and this patient had none of those cardinal symptoms.

Inhibition of carbonic anhydrase (Option B):

Seen with proximal renal tubular acidosis (Type 2 RTA) or with use of acetazolamide, this defect leads to bicarbonate wasting, causing metabolic acidosis (not alkalosis), often with hypokalemia. However, nephrocalcinosis is uncommon, and there is usually acidotic breathing and growth retardation in congenital forms. This patient is neither acidotic nor has typical signs of proximal RTA.

Pharmacological inhibition of the Na+-K+-2Cl- co-transporter (Option D):

This is the mechanism of loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide), which mimic Bartter syndrome by blocking the same transporter. While the resulting clinical picture can be similar (hypokalemia, alkalosis, nephrocalcinosis), urinary screen showed no evidence of diuretic use, and the chronicity of the problem supports a genetic cause over pharmacological inhibition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with Sjogren's syndrome presents with severe left-sided loin pain and haematuria. Blood tests reveal hypokalemia and acidosis. The anion gap is 10 mmol/l. There is hypercalciuria. Abdominal radiographs show a left ureteric calculus. What is the most likely cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 30-year-old woman has Sjogren's syndrome, a condition commonly associated with distal (type 1) renal tubular acidosis. She presents with loin pain, haematuria, hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, and a ureteric stone-all classic findings of type 1 RTA. The normal anion gap (10 mmol/L) points to a non-anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis, characteristic of RTA. The failure to acidify the urine leads to calcium phosphate stone formation, explaining the calculus seen on imaging.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Uraemic acidosis (Option A):

This refers to the acidosis seen in advanced chronic kidney disease, typically with elevated creatinine/urea levels and a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. This patient has no evidence of renal failure or elevated anion gap, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Primary hyperaldosteronism (Option B):

Characterized by hypokalemia, hypertension, and metabolic alkalosis due to aldosterone-mediated hydrogen ion loss. This patient is acidotic, not alkalotic, and has no mention of hypertension, so this is an incorrect choice.

Lactic acidosis (Option D):

Usually results in a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to accumulation of lactate. It is commonly seen in shock, hypoxia, or sepsis-none of which apply here. This patient has a normal anion gap, ruling out lactic acidosis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old diabetic man presents for review. His annual review bloods reveal a raised creatinine of 1.65 mg/dl, potassium of 5.9 mmol/l and bicarbonate of 19 mmol/l. Urinary protein excretion is normal. His blood pH is 7.0. What diagnosis fits best with this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis is Type 4 Renal Tubular Acidosis, which is characterized by:

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Mild to moderate metabolic acidosis
  • Mildly reduced renal function
  • Often seen in diabetic patients, due to hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism.

This form of RTA is associated with reduced aldosterone effect, leading to impaired distal tubular acid and potassium secretion.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Type I RTA (Option B):

This typically presents with hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia. It involves impaired H+ secretion in the distal tubule, leading to alkaline urine, nephrocalcinosis, and kidney stones. The patient also usually has normal or low K+, unlike this case.

Gordon Syndrome (Option C):

Also known as pseudohypoaldosteronism type II, it causes hyperkalemia and hypertension with metabolic acidosis, but it's typically seen in younger individuals and is genetic. This man has diabetes and normal BP, making Gordon syndrome less likely.

Pseudohypoaldosteronism (Option D):

This usually presents in infants or young children with salt wasting, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and severe volume depletion. The patient here is a 54-year-old with no signs of salt wasting or hypotension, making this unlikely.

choices.text: Inhibition of carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule

questions.text: A woman with long-standing glaucoma and type-2 diabetes is admitted for an ophthalmological procedure. Her current medications include acetazolamide, metformin and atenolol. The operation is postponed because of an abnormal blood test, although she is asymptomatic. Plasma Na+: 137 mmol/l, K+: 3.0 mmol/l, chloride: 115 mmol/l and bicarbonate: 15 mmol/l. Arterial pH is 7.26 and pCO2 is 21.7 mm Hg. What is the probable pathophysiology responsible for the acid-base disturbance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient is on acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor commonly used for glaucoma. Carbonic anhydrase plays a key role in bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule of the nephron.

When inhibited, there is decreased reabsorption of bicarbonate and increased excretion of bicarbonate in the urine. This leads to a loss of base, resulting in a metabolic acidosis. Because bicarbonate is lost without the generation of organic acids, the anion gap remains normal.

To maintain electroneutrality, the kidney retains chloride, leading to a hyperchloremic (normal anion gap) metabolic acidosis. Her blood gas and chemistry findings - low bicarbonate (15 mmol/L), low pH (7.26), low pCO2 (21.7 mmHg), elevated chloride (115 mmol/L), and normal sodium - support this diagnosis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Ketoacidosis (Option B):

Ketoacidosis, typically seen in uncontrolled diabetes or prolonged fasting, causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosisdue to accumulation of ketone bodies (acetoacetate, β-hydroxybutyrate). This patient, however, has a normal anion gap(137 - [115 + 15] = 7), making ketoacidosis unlikely. Additionally, she is asymptomatic and has no mention of elevated glucose, dehydration, or ketones.

Metformin-induced lactic acidosis (Option C):

Lactic acidosis due to metformin use is also a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, as lactate accumulation increases the anion gap. It usually occurs in the setting of renal impairment or hypoperfusion and is typically symptomatic. In this case, the patient is asymptomatic, her anion gap is normal, and there is no evidence of systemic illness or shock, making this diagnosis improbable.

Stress-induced hyperventilation (Option D):

Hyperventilation from anxiety or stress leads to respiratory alkalosis, not acidosis. It causes excessive exhalation of CO2, raising blood pH. While this patient does have low pCO2 (a compensatory response), her primary disturbance is metabolic acidosis, as evidenced by the low pH and low bicarbonate. Therefore, stress-induced hyperventilation is not responsible for her acid-base imbalance.

choices.text: Urinary pH in Type I can be lowered below pH 5.3 after ammonium chloride administration

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with muscle weakness and lethargy. Her plasma sodium is 138 mmol/l, potassium 2.1 mmol/l, bicarbonate 12 mmol/l and chloride 113 mmol/l. Creatinine is 0.62 mg/dl. She is diagnosed as having type I renal tubular acidosis(RTA). What is the most significant clinical presentation of distal renal tubular acidosis(type I) that differentiates it from proximal renal tubular acidosis(type II)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has distal (type I) renal tubular acidosis (RTA), as suggested by:

  • Low bicarbonate (12 mmol/L) → metabolic acidosis
  • Hypokalemia (K+ 2.1 mmol/L)
  • Normal creatinine → preserved GFR
  • Hyperchloremia (Cl- 113 mmol/L) → normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) acidosis
  • Normal sodium (Na+ 138 mmol/L)

The key distinguishing feature of distal (type I) RTA is the inability of the distal nephron to acidify urine, which leads to:

  • Alkaline urine (pH > 5.5) despite systemic acidosis
  • Increased risk of calcium phosphate stone formation and nephrocalcinosis due to chronic urinary alkalinity and increased calcium excretion.

Thus, the most significant clinical feature that differentiates type I from type II RTA is renal stone formation, which is much more common in distal RTA (type I) and not typically seen in proximal RTA (type II).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Failure to thrive (Option A):

While this can occur in both type I and type II RTA, especially in children, it is not a distinguishing feature between the two.

Urinary pH in Type I can be lowered below pH 5.3 after ammonium chloride administration (Option C):

This statement is false. In distal RTA (type I), the urinary pH remains above 5.3 even after acid loading (e.g., with ammonium chloride), because the distal tubule cannot excrete H adequately. In contrast, in proximal RTA (type II), the distal nephron is intact, and urine pH can fall below 5.3 after acid loading.

Metabolic acidosis is common (Option D):

This is true, but it is common to all types of RTA, and therefore does not distinguish between type I and type II.
